topic.title: hub-based ideas: neozities (like geocities/neocities) and zlogger (zeronetblogger)
topic.body:
Why not more hub-based portal-zites?

Like a zite that allows every user to easily add his/her 10mb personal space on Zn?

Not like twitter aka zerome, but more a personal home that links to other zn places like zerome, zeromedium or wherever.

Or a hub-based portal-zite for bloggers, so people simply host their blog on a hub instead of cloning all the time, then the main zite could automatically aggregate and show + link all blogs, categorize them, add moderation etc.

Would surely save some bookmarks space on the left and add a common update and moderation mechanism in the future, so any user gets updated features etc. without bothering updating the underlying code themselves.

As a bonus any user could share files with other portal-zites if "CDN" is used as hub-merger-type.

topic.title: some new pdf books channel on IFS - feature request
topic.body:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:channel+id:1Mz1_1CthCNo2eADyWkShCTBTVKGHy3WNXcj6Fh

Anyone can do a demo zite with an online js bookreader that could open and display such a pdf within zeronet?

Simply allow merger type CDN to display a linked resource from IFS.

topic.title: Superpeers that help seeding and spread the power of 0net
topic.body:
A superpeer should be online 24/7 and have enough storage capacity to help seed big files automatically by enabling "autodownload" content on hubs/clusters.

Whether superpeers are clearnet accessible or only accessible from within zeronet doesnt matter.

E.g. the operator of this proxy could help distribute all files by clicking on the right switch on this IFS hub:
https://0net.io/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:clusters+id:1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr

Generally any zeronet client can this way become a superpeer/supernode if operated without downtimes and having the available bandwith/hdd space available.

Also anyone could help spreading the word by linking to public supernodes content, as it is a good way to showcase the power of ZN to clearnet users like on reddit, e.g. by linking video content and explaining why this is better than half-decentralized services like dtube or steemit:
https://0net.io/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz1_1CthCNo2eADyWkShCTBTVKGHy3WNXcj6Fh_item_18+type:video

topic.title: Zerovoat: Some missing topics on proxy and vice versa?
topic.body:
A)

I can see this topic here local:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb/index.html?v=topic+id=1R67TfYzNkCnh89EFfGmXn5LMb4hXaMRQ4

B)

Vice versa this topic is visible on the proxy:
https://0net.io/1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb/index.html?v=topic+id=15gHmNjxH8v82YMkFSxKPr4etHVZxLSHAmtopic1

Anyone can report to see topic A) or B) local?
Any idea why this happens?

Thanks for helping testing.

topic.title: Zerovoat now with easy media deletion / blocking within ZN and default clearnet media blocking

1532224996_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
> [zeropyro](#comment_13_1KsFe6vgVpNFCNTQDQryrcQYySkAbFLXCV): And the same thing on KopyKate,YouTube on 0Net,.This zites have 24/7 seed so they are loaded.But you can not watch a video on this zites.

Try IFS, without need for webseed torrents over clearnet:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/

> [zeropyro](#comment_15_1KsFe6vgVpNFCNTQDQryrcQYySkAbFLXCV): This point the program not download later if the seeder goes online. There is no such problem in similar p2p cilents.This is a serious development bug.This thing is causing serious problems throughout the network.

Agree it would be big step forward if ZN-client work like P2P-client and try automatically reconnect and finish all big files with missing parts of piecemap.

libtorrent doesnt give you automatic tor protection even with zeronet=tor always.
With all those 3 strike rules and cease and desist letters, this exposes people to high risk without their knowledge, similar to intentional embedded clearnet content.
Imo everything should be routed through ZN, thats why BFS of ZN is a great step forward and only lacks autoreconnect when a new peer goes online at a later point in time and serves missing chunks to anyone who having the corresponding piecemap.

> [lola](#comment_62_1KuwwnkAtVrfnyhv8pyGRxLqzNZbEkJt2u): True the libtorrent plugin can be an issue for anonymity. I will make sure it is clear for everyone. [...]

How? It is impossible without using VPN.
Otherwise anyone sharing a video is risk to a cease and desist, the same as when uploading content via a normal torrent client and no VPN.
It is imo even more dangerous as people might not be aware they are revealing their iP automatically by clicking on any video thats copyrighted on your service. They think they are safe/protected by using ZN via tor=always, but your plugin is circumventing tor protection and risking anyone to be easilly exposed without a VPN.

Same goes for any IPFS based solution within ZN, where anonymity is not provided.

Imo solutions like IFS are better because they stay fully within ZN and therefore giving tor protection when downloading big files via ZNs own solution via piecemaps and merkle trees.

1531922152_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
Auto-resume as an attempt to finish any partly downloaded BF should be a top priority for ZN.

Like a bittorrent client, if a user keeps ZN running for 24 hours every unfinished, but requested BF should be attempting to complete download any missing merkle chunks as soon as some other peer comes up that has a missing piece.

So if the user keeps ZN running overnight and wakes up, most stuff should be complete if some other peer connected that carried the missing pieces.

Otherwise people will just click on a BF one time and if failed may never bother re-checking just to kickstart the download process manually over and over again.

@nofish: Is implementing a default autocomplete mode for big files with fetched piecemaps possible?

1533160269_1JHx7fetxzMnUyQ5bUpNLAKAW9VEZ.body: What is Beaker browser based on? Chromium (=fail)?

> [nicwow](#comment_22_1JHx7fetxzMnUyQ5bUpNLAKAW9VEZdbFMa): Chromium = FOSS so, no not an immediate fail. I would only say it is a fail if they left all the Google bits and didn't remove them. It seems like they must have removed then or it wouldn't be as popular among hobbyists. I would have preferred they would have used FireFox ESR but, I will say Chromium arguably has a better UI. But I wish my FireFox extensions were supported as I hate downloading stuff from the Chrome store.This is definitely a plus for ZeroNet as any web browser works with it. A little frustrating that to visit a site you must do http://127.0.0.1:43110/{site URL/hash}, though.

Until now, it is impossible to remove all google bits, blobs and blackbox binaries.
Ask TOR devs why they never would recommend any security related project to be based on chromium.
There is still ongoing "ungoogle" project, but even they have almost given up in the past:
https://github.com/Eloston/ungoogled-chromium

> [marketforce](#comment_36_1ENvPHLeuUKJAWsup9tL9C1mdZeb1ycjp8): It's based on Electron so yes, Chromium.Fail? Sure.  [...]

Yes, Firefox is not perfect either (nothing is), but it is at least not inherently flawed from the beginning for what is known.
People thinking opensource=good is not true, since if the project is too big, like android or chrome, simply opensourcing it doesn't change anything if the original is built on purpose to compromise its users in all kinds of possible ways.
Imagine MS opensourcing Windows wouldn't likely make it any better alternative compared to Linux in regards of user security.
So choosing the lesser known evil, like in case of the tor-browser the firefox engine, should be the base requirement for any trustworthy program that has the goal of benefitting the user through more freedom/privacy/security, which in case of using chromium as base is a lost cause (=fail) from the start.

1534470841_1Kh3qLdTH2QKewUb6cWZa2dMveMT5.body:

1535288109_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJV.body:
Thats why people should use "Save as zip" from the dropdown menu of each site to simulate something like archive.is or archive.org. So if some site owner does weird things, one could continue under a new adress.

Would be great if someone actually did try setup a backup of some site and post here just to see if it works.

Especially with merger zites, one could try only cloning the frontend to a new site adress and then see what happens if two frontends for the same backend hub sites exist and both can manipulate content on the same hubs?

1536480860_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2.body:
Better use IFS for sharing any file types:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/

It is using 100% zeronet tech like BigFileSupport, so not bypassing TOR as with any webtorrent zite.

> [kaffie](#comment_654_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): It's not obsolete. It just never caught on in the first place. For zeronet files, it was used for a little bit, but the big file support is much better, so we use that instead.

It would be cool to use the same hub-types then and make them all of merger type : CDN.
That way, any content can be shared potentially by any other frontend.

> [robione](#comment_27_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): you didn't actually answer the question. What/where?

Intergalactic File Server - IFS:
https://0net.io/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/

It is a potential "archive.org" like zite for ZN.

IFS uses big files and displays downloaded chunks via a green download bar, similar to torrent clients.
Can play videos, music and also some other content like games directly from the browser:
https://0net.io/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1_1C1gnFcVv9J9kUjF4odDMRYcEWVPJbbqFp_item_166+type:game

> [robione](#comment_28_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): ZN is mostly small files.Replication is inefficient. Stores all accessed data at every node.Dispersing bits of files across many nodes in a way they can be reconstructed (using erasure codes) is much more efficient.

ZN now has BiGFileSupport, which uses merkle trees in a very effecient way.
Therefore also big files can be loaded and ditributed FAST, e.g.:
https://0net.io/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz1_1CthCNo2eADyWkShCTBTVKGHy3WNXcj6Fh_item_18+type:video

Try the above link in yourown local instance to see how fast it is.

Dispersion or other methods can likely be added at any point in time also in ZN (like MerkelTreeSupport before), should it be needed and not go against TOR protection, which most things are struggling to combine, hence ZN is almost the only fast and secure decentralized system currently available that work ootb.

> [kaffie](#comment_655_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Replication is more important than HDD space. We have all the space we need. Tons of it. Terabytes upon terabytes.

Exactly, space is no longer an issue even with homeusers, so anyone can become a supernode by using a rpi3+hard drive attached and replicate serve content 24/7.

> [kaffie](#comment_659_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Something like TPB or KAT would work. As it stands it kinda just looks like one of those shitty spam sites.

Feel free to simply clone and do a new frontend :)

> [robione](#comment_31_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): It would be interesting to have a crawler mode for IFS and anyone else running a supernode that is willing to cache things on upload (like 0net.io).If it were a data dispersal based system, the initial upload would need to complete somewhere temporarily to avoid the source disappearing and leaving behind a dead link.

ZN default mode doesnt force any content onto other users systems unless requested.
But anyone can voluntarily turn a crawl mode on for any zite or merger zite:
Simply switch "help distribute all files" should grab anything immediately once it becomes available.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:clusters+id:1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr


So anyones system can become a supernode quite easily for various zites.

> [robione](#comment_36_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): How does one upload to IFS? It's not obvious.

From upper right dropdown:
1. Select "Create an account" from dropdown
2. choose identity from the certs available (zeroid or created ifs)
3. Choose "Select Account", hit refresh after selecting an ID
4. Go to "My Channels" in dropdown
5. Create a channel by clicking on the "+" (You can like on youtube create "channels" that you can thematically add files to).
6. upload files by selecting them from a local source.

Imo a complete waste of time to implement this into ZN, as it 99,9% will fail as soon as it gets bigger/more interesting to subvert.

1537746280_15hL2gR4oCSgKBbndn3MxY8Hc5xoy.body: How does it work compared to clearnet/centralized zeroid?

1538009272_1HrQ48VceWqeGu9qmC2Y8VxUsGNSJ.body:
Big Files are zn-native, which gives easy Tor protection which ipfs is missing.
If @nofish now also implements autodownload/resume + decoupling of big files via a global hash-based identification mechanism, zn bigfiles would have surpassed ipfs.

1538505571_15hL2gR4oCSgKBbndn3MxY8Hc5xoy.body: What is the benefit of running ZN over cjdns?

> [kaffie](#comment_715_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): cjdns handles mesh network routing and is very easy to set up. Most other mesh networking software is fairly complicated. cjdns, given that it works as an overlay, can also run over the regular internet as well, not just meshes. Which means that we're able to grow the network before moving off of the internet.

Thanks for the explanation. 
Can cjdns be used with Tor?
Would it be easier for any local zn node to become a reliable tracker because the ipv4 might change every 24 hours by the isp but the ipv6 of cjdns would not?

So its much more easy to build flexible zites around that focus on interaction, sorting, displaying than to always implement upload, filtering, valuating, etc. again for all zites.

1550918453_14XR9KNwgJhCv1RiuqKxjBDkCRETj.body:

1551299295_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5.body:
> [klu9](#comment_79_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Embedding a streamable video already on another site (e.g. Youtube) is a fairly typical blog activity on clearnet and I wanted to see if I can do it on 0net too.

That would require a revision of optional big files becoming global big files. You could add a ticket on github project as Feature request.

> [klu9](#comment_81_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): @gluek: I don't understand. Could you explain?

I loaded your website, but the video doesnt load. It is only shown when already in my ZN data folder as cache.
And for that to load I must visit the KopyKate zite before, your zite is not allowed to download the video by itself.

That is what I meant with to make this work, ZN needs to handle big files outside of their zite context.
This would also make it much easier to "combine" different local ZN master folders, like copying one "data-files" folder into another "data-files" folder, IF big files would be stored inside their own "data-files" folder instead of "data". There would be numerous advantages, this is just two.

> [klu9](#comment_82_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): @toyata: I understand now... I think :)So when attempting to embed an external video in a blog post, I should provide a link to the source and advice like:"If you can't see the video here, click the link to see it on [external source]."

Yes, that should work. The reason is that accessing an embedded file could trigger starting to download an endless number of nested zites and used as an attack method. Therefore ZN limits content to be from the same zite or merger type. One thing you could try as a "trick" is to declare your zite as the same merger type as KopyKate, if KopyKate is using the merger technology.

Here is an example:
Lets say you want to embed this video from IFS:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz1_12w3zJ6gRrcAw2kSCQXDkorgqxuXnkKkF8_item_6+type:video

To embed the video this would be the direct link:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/merged-CDN/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/12w3zJ6gRrcAw2kSCQXDkorgqxuXnkKkF8/BLADE_RUNNER_2049_-_2036_Nexus_Dawn_Short.mp4

To allow watching the video on your zite, you need to allow it to access from the same merger type, CDN.
To do this, go to your zite folder under data and add in content.json this line:
 "merger_name": "CDN",

This should do the trick and ask someone who never got access to the video and IFS before to grant access to the merger zite, where the video is stored.
After granting access, the video should load and play fine.

1551558721_1CVzc6Q13qL6MskGL9Ni7os6Gjfor.body:
Sounds like this could also be a use case for "universal big files" instead of current zite-dependent "optional big files".
That way the zite stores only meta-data and user-data like commnents, ratings, etc. and the actual file corresponding to the hash of the movie will be stored outside of that zite folder, in "data-files" folder inside ZeroNet-Master folder.

1551712265_1C1gnFcVv9J9kUjF4odDMRYcEWVPJ.body:

I thought the whole idea was, if someone doesnt like to continue or site vanishes, someone else can pick up or restore a lost site via "Save as zip" from a backup?
Does anybody know?

1551618955_163wft59zLGW1zNA6WBsppjFEbXxA.body: Thanks robione. So if you say gnunet could replace Namecoin .bit, how would domain names with GNS look like for ZN?

1557305635_16HcyFK8526ZYJBKPpSDCbpJv6WWB.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_842_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): If a site isn't marked as cloneable, you can still manually copy the source code by accessing the /data/ folder for your ZN. You just have to move it over by hand, rather than having an easy button. [...]

Thanks for your reply Kaffie.

When copying a zite by hand in data folder, incl. all user data like comments, votes or content, does it work as a 1:1 clone/copy of the original up to that point?

Could you demonstrate a 1:1 copy of this Zerotalk forum under a different ZN adress, so in case this forum would vanish overnight, it could be continued under the new adress with all content up to this point intact and fully functional for all users with zeroid?

I tried this by hand and couldnt get it to work... when trying to sign the Zerotalk zite after coping it 1:1 to a new zite, it skips ALL user content.

So the most i can get back up is an empty zite with all content and user contributions lost. Hopefully someone can prove this wrong and demonstrate a working clone...

Otherwise i would argue zeronet is no better than any centralized website (other than being distributed), but that offers no protection if the main site goes down or the creator chooses to remove it (exactly like with any other clearnet site going down).

Hey kaffie, glad there is someone interested to figure this out :)
Now i wonder why all user/data folders have to be signed again when cloned... as long as nothing changed from last signing, it shouldnt matter.
To prevent any manipulation, one could add a genetated hash to all files included in the user data folder at time of signing, then if someone clones or copies the site, do a quickcheck if all is still valid and then skip signing, but display user content normally.

As for hubs, it should have the same problem then?
Like if i begin to not trust a hub anymore, i cannot simply archive a full copy and bring it back on in case it goes down, if signing or rather validating user data folders is not possible with the clone.

Maybe @nofish can think of a solution and update python3 ZN to allow this validation to make ZN very robust against forced takedowns of individual users sites or hubs.

> [gitcenter](#comment_473_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): User content files include address field which must equal site address.

Thanks for the info. Kind of contrary to freedom and resilence of ZN though. I mean this is not blockchain, should be different. The whole centralized ZeroID and protection concepts around it kinda suck... its like first invent free flow water, then making it not wet: the only way is to freeze it completely.

1562000931_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:

Thats not fully working, as the content is still sort of centralized, and doesnt get copied as well.
Therefore the most important next step is to detach zites from content, e.g. to move all files into a data-files toplevel folder, so any content is then also reusable elsewhere, like big files.

> [geekless](#comment_65_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4): Which actually means we should move away from the "site" paradigm. There should be "applications" to access and operate data in personal and collective "hubs", and all those things should be located on separate addresses. [...]

Exactly this. ZN needs to restructure and open up the possibility to truly clone a zite/application and fully allow continously access to a set of data, much like any music player or book reader can access independently the same songs or ebooks to play or read and add meta-data to it that is then only relevant in the apps own context.

In a decentralized context, this deduplication is essential with regards to security and effeciency at the same time.

1563812717_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc3.body:
> [redlibertyreal](#comment_33_1D6UcmziWg55aXV6TnCksXpjsFJ4gDK6Kw): If anything I am skeptical about the future, my hope is reluctant, it's a hope for hope. As Slavoj Zizek (a communist) says, "today the light at the end of the tunnel is actually an incoming train". There is no "big other" with which one can use to justify this or that act or atrocity, but we have to fight in order to try and build a freer, more democratic, more just world even if the odds are stacked against us. Hope of a singing future then springs if anything, from our own efforts, futile though they may seem to be. I am skeptical of this so-called "historical inevitability", if anything it is one potential future, though I think and hope it's where we will be (think a more realistic Star Trek like world hundreds of years from now). As for a universal symbolism we have to look at the socioeconomic forces behind prevailing civilization (historical materialism) but also within the human spirit itself. People like to be free, people like to have control over their own lives and communities. I think these are good things but you are right there are dangers and if anything the 20th century is a startling reminder of that, it's something we can never forget. My problem is this absurd notion that "anything against individualism (or that I don't like) is COMMUNISM". You can't do that, just paint anything you don't like as socialism/ communism. Especially since when some of the most radical individualists in human history have themselves been communists, and especially in regards to ZeroNet when we communists on here do not say or think the things you say in this post that we say or think. This is my view, respectfully.

1566439997_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
Since ZN has introduced Big Files via merkle tree piecemaps, it is one step away from having a better implementation right on default. That step is sharing files by making site-wide only files universally available within ZNby restructuring how optional files are stored and referenced (hash). 

This parallel invent is imo necessary, since Ipfs and ZN share independent directions and philosophy, e.g. Ipfs censorship of official catalogs dont mix well with ZN user freedoms.

1566679861_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body: Zerovoat is a merger zite frontend of merger type CDN, meaning anyone can clone the interface and revamp it and point to the same content in parallel. So it can have as many interfaces as people can imagine and still all is shared and synced between all frontends, as the backend are simple clusters.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/19gtNiKNZMq6nTdWThGCQQAS2bCYAY1tFh/

There seems only one cluster though for the original master frontend, so whoever clones the frontend could extend it to allow more clusters.

Something that easily could backup any clearnet page, like archive.is, then deny any modification, store its hashvalue in blockchain to prove ehat the unmodified site-content was like at a certain point in time without any chance to manipulate that later.

> [filips](#comment_272_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): ZeroArchive is something like archive.is or archive.org. It just fetches whole website to local folder, indicates it with date and publishes that to ZeroNet. However, it doesn't prevent later modifications to that folder due how ZeroNet workd (but this might change soon). It also can't handle websites that heavily relies on JavaScript due how HTTRack works. [...]

1576144410_144CwRj8eynTUC9DtGHaNHR3wm9P2.body:
> [1bfqutudhtexlka](#comment_117_144CwRj8eynTUC9DtGHaNHR3wm9P2EhuAY): hope the developer add mute function ,also in the FAQ there is a moderation , which is a sad thing :(

Moderation can be turned off client side.

What IFS and any other zite needs is a better global moderation/mute/filterlist functionality, which of course anyone can add or remove clientside based on their preferences. These will work just like addblock filterlists.
To get this feature, ZN needs to finally implement universal optional files UOF, which are referenced and shared by hash. This would allow for above suggested unified zn-wide mutelists, so chances are slim some unwanted content "slips through", as is high chances for all local moderated zites currently. Note that this would not censor anything, as no filterlist could be forced on users, and any filterlist could be completely checked for the validity of its moderated content. 

The interesting point is how to argue such lists legally. Imo they would be on the same scale as googles warnlists of "bad content", just fully transparent and people driven, instead of intransparent and corporate driven.
